msIdentifier.collection: Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, Main Collection

note.p: Joshua S. Morris was an attorney general of Mississippi during the Reconstruction era.

Born in 1827 in Claiborne County, Mississippi, Morris became a practicing attorney in Vicksburg and Natchez. Aside from his legal work, he was known locally for his poems and short stories, including “The Harp of a Thousand Strings.”

After the Civil War, Morris became a Republican in support of federal Reconstruction. He was appointed attorney general of Mississippi in 1870 and served in that capacity until 1874. He died on February 12, 1890. Morris was married twice; first to Agnes Willis, who passed away in 1875. He then married Gertrude Cameron. He had at least five children.

(Wikipedia; Natchez Democrat, Natchez, MS, February 14, 1890; Joshua S. Morris, “The Harp of a Thousand Strings,” The World’s Wit and Humor: An Encyclopedia in 15 Volumes, 1906, Bartleby.com; Vicksburg Whig, Vicksburg, MS, March 7, 1860; FindaGrave; 1880 U.S. Census for Warren, Mississippi, Roll 667, page 560a)
Joshua S. Morris belonged to the following social groups:
Located in southwest Mississippi, Warren County was established December 22, 1809. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia)

gloss.p: "The crime of intentionally killing a person." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Having officially been found guilty of a crime in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The legal punishment of killing someone." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to give advice to people about the law and speak for them in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A lawyer who acts for the government against someone accused of a crime in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who works in an office, dealing with records or performing general office duties." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A group of people who have been chosen to listen to the facts in a court action and decide whether a person is guilty or not guilty or whether a claim has been proved." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where criminals are kept as a punishment for their crimes or while waiting for trials." (Cambridge Dictionary)
While the Cambridge Dictionary defines death as “the end of life,” CWRGM employs this subject tag to refer to human deaths only, both actual and hypothetical. (Cambridge Dictionary)

The nation experienced mass loss of life (approximately 2% of the population) during the American Civil War, which changed the way Americans viewed death and resulted in its reconceptualization in highly bureaucratized ways. Often wartime dead were buried without their names and sometimes in poorly-dug graves, which created a powerful, profound social and cultural dislocation for their surviving loved ones. During the 19th century, Americans understood dying as a social and religious experience, and desired a "good death," which they defined as at home surrounded by family, but these ideals were unattainable in war. Consequently, Americans learned to cope with death and memorialize it in new ways. Unionists encouraged the federal government and ex-Confederates pushed their respective state governments to create and fund national cemeteries, rebury deceases soldiers and veterans, and establish veterans' and widows' pensions. These new responses to death were more bureaucratized, nationalistic, and secularized. Wartime and post-war death was also highly impacted by race, as white supremacists desecrated the graves of Union buried in the South, especially the bodies of African Americans who served in U.S. Colored Troops and the white officers that led them, revealing post-war sectionalism and strains on reconciliation. (Drew Gilpin Faust, This Republic of Suffering)

element.label: Description
element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Alcorn Collection. Legal document from Frank Halliday, clerk of the criminal court of Warren County, Mississippi, showing an order of judgement from the court stating that Robert Woods has been found guilty of the charge of murder and is sentenced to death by hanging. The sentence is to be carried out on April 30, 1870.

div.p:
THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI
WARREN COUNTY.
Sct.

AT a Term of the Criminal Court of said State, held in and for the County aforesaid, at the Court House thereof, on the 5" day of March in the year of our Lord, one thousand, eight hundred and seventy

Present:
Hon. E. H. Osgood, Judge.
J. S. Morris, Dist. Att'y.
Chas. E. Furlong, Sheriff.
F. Halliday, Clerk.
Among other proceedings in said Court, on the day and year aforesaid, was the following, to—wit:

THE STATE,
vs.
Robert Woods
Murder

This day came the District Attorney who prosecutes for and on behalf of the State, and the said Defendant was led to the Bar in the custody of the Sheriff of Warren County, and the said Defend-ant having, at a former day of this Term of the Court, been convicted of the crime of Murder, It is therefore considered by the Court that the said Robert Woods, for the crime of Murder, of which he stands convicted by the Verdict of a Jury aforesaid, be taken from the Bar of this Court to the Jail of the County of Warren, and be from thence taken on the 30" day of April at 12 oclock. m. A. D. 1870, to the place of execution appointed by Law, and be there hanged, by the neck, until he be dead; and that the Sheriff of Warren County execute this Judgment.
I, FRANK HALLIDAY, Clerk of the Criminal Court of Warren County, certify that the above and foregoing is a true copy from the minutes of said Court.
IN TESTIMONY WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand and affixed the seal of said Court, this 8" day of March, 1870

Feby Term, A. D., 1870.
THE STATE
vs. } Sentence.
Robert Woods
Death by hanging Years.
